 Foreword The explosion of international migration in the Middle East and North Africa Region in the 1970s was a major development on the international economic scene with profound implications for both the labor-importing and the labor-exporting countries. The World Bank undertook a research study on the subject in 1978 under the leadership of Ismail Serageldin and his group of committed colleagues in the Technical Assistance and Special Studies Division of the EMENA Projects Department. The study was completed in 1981 and the Report has been widely disseminated. It has been published in book form this year. 1/ The set of simulation models developed by the Technical Assistance and Special Studies Division and elaborated during the research project has been applied to study manpower problems and planning issues in several countries and proven to be a useful tool for manpower planning. The wide availability and a full description of these models is important and to be welcomed. Vinod Dubey Chief Economist Europe, Middle East and North Africa Region May 1983 1/ Ismail Serageldin, James A. Socknat, Stace Birks, Bob Li, and Clive Sinclair, Manpower and International Labor Migration in the Middle East and North Africa (Oxford University Press for the World Bank, 1983). v

 Preface This document, published in four volumes as part of the World Bank's staff working papers, is intended to set forth the mathematical formulation of the Bank's various Manpower Planning Models, most of which have now been used in a number of countries and studies, but whose technical documentation was not hitherto available to the public. Applied Models are living entities, constantly changing and (we hope) improving to meet the new requirements introduced by their users. The present publication must therefore be seen as a snapshot in time, but one which presents the interested user with the opportunity of reviewing the technical documentation as well as the user's guides as they stand at the beginning of 1983. They are not likely to change significantly until a new round of intensive applications produces a new generation. The technicaI presentation provides, for completeness, a detailed discussion (pp. 98-132) of a simultaneous procedure method for the migration model. This has not been implemented to date, partly because time and resources constraints prevented its complete development and elaboration, but it nevertheless sketches out the likely direction of our next round of research and development efforts, planned for 1983/84. It is important to emphasize, however, that while we were the main protagonists in the development of these models, the work would not have been possible without the support, guidance and incisive comments of many colleagues in and outside the Bank. To all of them we owe a great debt of intellectual and moral gratitude. We emphasize, however, that any errors or shortcomings in the present manuscript are purely our own. vii

 Note The purpose of this User's Guide for the Country (Compound) Model is to describe the input, output, use, and operation of the Compound Model, a manpower forecasting model, implemented for IBM 370 systems. Staff of the Technical Assistance and Special Studies (TASS) Division of the World Bank are available, under appropriate arrangements, to discuss with potential users the collection and preparation of required input data for running the Model. In some cases, the TASS Division can also conduct short orientation and training sessions on the capabilities and operation of the Model. Those users who wish to know about the internal and external system specifications of the Compound Model, should refer to the following documents, available on request from the TASS Division; - An Integrated Computer Based Manpower Planning Model; Subroute Descriptions and Flow Charts; - The Compound Model; General Approach and Internal Specifications; - The Compound Model; External Specifications; Input/Output; - The Compound Model; The Allocation of Manpower Supply; and - The Compound Model: A Linear Programming Approach to Expatriate Manpower Allocation. x

 INTRODUCTION The Compound Model provides an analytical tool to facilitate the initiation, updating and evaluation of manpower forecasts. The model adopts the approach of portraying a country as a whole, where manpower inventories, demand, and supplies, including importation of expatriates, are simulated over time. The model is deterministic, that is, all future events 6f the dynamic interactions are simulated according to specified procedures without involving random elements. The model is designed to contain and handle essential details representative of the country's manpower inventories, demand, and supplies conditions. It is not overwhelmed by attempting to simulate all the details of every event. The model's utility, in fact, resides as much in its rejection of inessential details as in its retention of essentials. To start a manpower forecasting exercise, it is necessary to begin with the collection of relevant data which may or may not be readily available. If dataate not available, subjective judgement must be exercised to provide estimates. This is not an easy task. It may just be one of the most difficult steps in the whole exercise.
 -2- The forecasting of manpower requirements and supplies is only one aspect of the Compound Model applications. Another aspect is the evaluation of various manpower oriented strategies. The evaluation of the impact of these strategies on manpower and economic development would assist decision makers in selecting the most suitable policies. The Compound Model can aid in the evaluation and selection process by providing analyses of the possible consequences of these strategies. Without a comprehensive manpower model, the evaluation and comparison of various manpower strategies would almost be impossible. Model building involves many different disciplines. How effectively one uses the model depends very much on the user's ex- perience. It is highly recommended that a team with experience in the field of economic, manpower, education, and system analysis be assigned to collect data, run the Compound Model, analyze the results of the simulation run, and prepare reports and recommendations to be submitted to decision makers for action.
 - 3 - 'SECTION I OVERVIEW OF THE'MODEL'DESIGN The Compound Model contains several interrelated submodels. The figure on next page presents an overview of the relationships among the submodels and of some of the variables contained therein. The submodels are: (1) Labor Force Model (2) Manpower Requirement Model (3) Education Simulation Model (4) Manpower Policy Model. The Labor Force'Model calculates the available labor force at the beginning of each simulation year by sectoral/occupational categories, including expatriates residing in the country. The stock of manpower available is then updated to reflect labor force attrition, the supply from the educational system and the net importation of expatriates. The Manpower Requirements Model accounts for: (a) the total manpower requirements to achieve a given target output by sector and occupational categories, taking into account, if necessary, productivities in each sector; and
 -4- Simplifed Schema of ihe Manpower Model Labor Form| (b) the net Manpower nto ata mp Requirements 2 ~~~Model (MRM) available manpowerMastock. =oernent theusermaySishltiou Model (MPM) |Model (ESM) i (b) the net manpower requirements by sector and occupational cstegories after comparing the total manpower requirements against the available manpower stock. It is to be noted that for selected sectors (e.g. Petroleum and Goverrnment) the user may wish to use the option of entering manpower requirements directly because better data are often available from officials in such key sectors than what would be generated by use of proJection techniques. Also, teacher requirements may be estimated by
 the Education Simulation Model, taking into account enroliment figures and teacher-student ratios, among other variables. This technique of estimating teacher requirements is an optional feature of the model. The Education Simulation Model (ESM), originally developed by UNESCO, estimates school leavers by age and level. However, not all of the school leavers participate in the labor force; some are below the legal minimum age to enter the labor force; others do not participate because of social, cultural and other reasons. These facts are taken into account by introducing a time dependent filter matrix. The school leavers who enter the labor force are pooled into groupings with similar educational level attainments. The Manpower Policy Model compared the net manpower requirements against manpower supplies from the educational system, and attempts to allocate manpower in accordance with a priority matrix where the priority and proportion of nationalization in each sector/occupation are specified by policy makers. After this has been done, labor policies on importation or exportation of expatriates are taken into account by exercizing a linear programming feasibility model (as contrasted to an optimization model) which operates on policy constraints. Finally, a by-product of the system is worth mentioning. The system calculates the existing labor force including national and expatriate labor already residing in the country, and, at the same time, also calculates the manpower supply from the ESM. From this set of data, the system estimates the achievable sectoral output based on the existing labor in the country without importing additional foreign labor.

 - 7 - SECTION 2 SUMMARY DESCRIPTION OF OPERATION Purpose The purpose of this section is to provide a summary des- cription of how to use the Compound Model residing on the George 1/ Washington University Computer (IBM 370/1485, The user of the Compound Model should be thoroughly familiar with the content of this Operational Manual before attempting to run the model. Overview of the Compound Model System From a user's point of view, the Compound Model system looks as depicted in the fieure below: MASTER MASTER FILE COMPOUND FILE _ ~~~~~~~MODELl INPUTREOS CARDS l_SYSTEM_ REPORTS_ On the input side (left side of the picture), the Model receives input cards and a masterfile containing information which is used by the Model to calculate projection data. On the output side, the Model presents the calculated data on reports and, optionally, pro- duces an updated version of the master file. The computer execution of the Compound Model system is conducted serially in six steps: EDIT PASS5 LKEDT MODEL REPORT SUMRY 1/ The only difference in the operation of the Compound Model residing on other computer installations is in the format of the IBM Job Con- trol Card (see paragraph "IBM System Control Input" in this section).
 -8- The EDIT step reads data from input cards and master file and checks for their validity. Any data errors are displayed on the Error Messages Report (See Section 4). Major errors cause the computer run to be terminated. If this happens, the user must correct the errors in the input data and re-submit the run to the computer center. The PASS5 step prints all input data (from cards and from master file) on the Input Data Report. The LKEDT step assembles the programs required by the MODEL step in a way that can be used by the computer to run that step. The MODEL step performs all projections of the Compound Model. These include: Labor Force, Manpower Requirements, Educational Systems, and Manpower Policy projections. The REPORT step formats the projection data produced by the MODEL step and generates all Compound Model reports. The SUMRY step collects certain major projection data and formats them into the Highlights Report.
 -9- Types of Output Produced by the Compound Model The following types of output are produced with each Compound Model computer run: - IBM Job Control Listing (JCL listing) - Master File Listing (only if a master file is created during the run) - Input Data Error Messages Report - Input Listing (for both master file and card input) - Educational Simulation Model Reports - Compound Model Reports - Highlights Report From a run control point of view, only the first four types of reports are of interest, since they provide all the information required to ensure that the computer run is executed successfully. Types of Input Required to Run the Compound Model To run the Model, three types gf input are required: - IBM system control input (JCL Cards) - Compound Model control input - Compound Model data inpkt
 - 10 - IBM System Control Input Three JCL cards are required to run the Compound Model: //JOBNAME JOB (800346,N,30,50,30),'USERNAME' // EXEC MANPOWER,COPIES=N (where N = number of report copies desired) 1/ These cards must be the first, second, and last card of the input deck. Compound Model Control Input Four Compound Model control cards are required to run the Model. Additionally, two other cards may also be used at the option of the user (for a detailed description of the cards content, see Section 6 ): Required cards: CO1: Run Control (this card must be placed just after the second JCL card in the input deck) C02: Run Title C03: Years.of Projection G05: Report Selection Optional cards: GO1: Analyst Name G06: Report Distribution List
 Compound Model Data Input Data input to the Compound Model is punched on the following card types: DO1 to D20 (Manpower Demand Cards) EO1 to E09 (ESM Cards) G02 to G04 (Definition Cards) G07 (Footnote Card) LO1 to L04 (Labor Force Data Cards) P01 to P08 (Manpower Policy Cards) S01 to S10 (Manpower Supply Cards) Detailed description of the cards content are found in Section 6. Organization of Input Deck The organization of the input deck to the Compound Model is displayed below: JCL Job Card 1st card JCL EXEC Card 2nd card CO1 Card 3rd card All other cards // last card.
 - 12 - Mode& of Operation The Compound Model can operate in three modes: - Base year run - Simulation run - Update run In a Base Year run (at B-run), all input data on cards are transferred to a master file which can be later used for Simulation or Updating runs. In a Simulation run (S-run), the master file created in a Base Year or Updating run is used as input to the Model. Data content of the master file can be temporarily changed for a particular run only, by using input cards to override master file data. In the Updating run (U-run), the master file created in a Base Year run or in a previous Updating run is used as input to the Model. Data content of the master file is permanently changed by using input cards to override master file data (thus, creating a new master file). After processing the input data as described above, all three types of runs perform projections as requested in the Compound Model control cards (i.e., cards C03 and G05). The type of run is specified in the COI card by punching a B (Base year run), or a S (Simulation run), or an U (Updating run) in card column 11. (For details please refer to Section 3). Important Note: When creating a new file (B or U run), in addition to specifying the new file name on the CO1 card (card columns 12-23), a system programmer must be contacted in order to allocate space for the new file in the computer.
 - 13 - Checking'the Compound Model Output After running the model, the user should check four reports to insure that the computer run terminated normally. The reports are: - IBM Job Control Listing - Master File Listing (B-run and U-run only) - Input Data Error Messages Report - Input Listing IBM Job Control Listing (JVL'Listing) This report contains a listing of all JCL statements used in the model. An indication of systems failure (abnormal termination) is given at the beginning of the report, in the first four or five lines. The message is "JOB FAILED." If this message is present, please give the entire output to a system programmer. He will help you in locating and correcting the error. If the message is not present, then the run terminated normally. There are two most common reasons for a system failure. The first reason is due to IBM control cards errors (JCL errors). This is indicated by the message: JOB FAILED - JCL ERROR. The second reason is due to the fact that there may not be enough space in the computer to run the model. This is indicated by the message: JOB FAILED - WAITING FOR ALLOCATION Other errors may occur occasionally. However, if they do, they all require assistance from a system programmer as mentioned above.
 - 14 - Master File Listing A listing of the data content of the master file is produced only in B or U-runs. When produced, the listing should be checked against the input data on cards to make sure that all input has been transferred to the master file. If the master file does not contain all input data, check the Error Messages Report to determine the cause. Input Data Error Messages Report Input data (either on the master file or on input cards) that do not satisfy the validity checks performed in the EDIT step are printed in this report together with explanatory messages (see Section 8). Major errors printed on this report cause the run to be terminated. The input cards containing the erroneous data must be corrected by using the Corrective Action written alongside the error message (see Section 8) and the run re-submitted to the computer. Input Listing All valid data input is formatted for easy reading and printed on this report. The user should check the listing to insure that the Model has received all the input required for the particular run.
 - 15 - SECTION 3 MODES OF OPERATION The Compound Model can operate in three modes: - Base Year run (B-run) - Simulation run (S-run) - Update run (U-run) The three types of runs differ in that each is treating the master file generation and processing in a unique way. However, each run type performs projections as requested by the Compound Model input data. Following is a description of each of the three modes. Base Year Run (B-run): The Base Year run requires as input a card deck containing the entire set of Compound Model input data. The input data cards are edited by the system and stored in a master file which is saved for later use. Both valid and non-valid data cards are stored in the master file. Each card within a specific card type (first three card columns, see Section 5), is automatically given a sequence number starting from 001 for the first card of a card type to a maximum of 998, in increments of 2 (i.e., 001, 003, 005, etc). If there are more than 449 cards in a card type, the remainder of the cards will all contain a sequence number of 998. The automatic assignment of sequence numbers to input cards is independent of the sequence number that might be contained on the input cards (card
 - 16 - columns 4 to 6, see Section 5 ) which, for B-runs only, is disregarded (i.e., input cards for B-runs could be prepared with blank sequence number fields). The Base Year run produces a listing displaying the content of the generated master file. Simulation Run (S-run): In a simulation run, the master file created in a Base Year run (or during an U.pdate run, see below) is used as input. Data content of the master file can be temp6tarily changed for a particular run only, by using input cards to override master file data. When changing the content of the master file, the user must use the sequence number as the key to the change. Input cards containing a card type and sequence number Ccard columns 1 to 6, see Section 5) identical to the card type and sequence number of the information in the master file, will replace that information. Input cards containing a new card type and/or a new sequence number which does not exist in the master file, will be insetted in the master file. Input cards which contain a card type and sequence number identical to the card type and sequence number of the information in the master file, and which also contain the keyword "DEL" in card columns 7 to 9, will delete that information.
 - 17 - To delete a range of sequence numbers from the master file, the user can enter the beginning sequence number of the range in card columns 4 to 6, and the ending sequence number in card columns 11 to 13 (card type, columns 1 to 3, and keyword "DEL", columns 7 to 9, must also be entered). No master file listing is produced by the Simulation run. Update Run (U-run): The Update run has the same capabilities as the Simulation run. However, the content of the master file is permainntly changed by the content of the input cards. The changed master file is saved for later use. The old master file (without the new changes) is kept untouched and is still available (saved) if needed. The Update run produces a listing displaying the content of the new (changed) iaster file.

An indication of system failure (abnormal termination) is given at the beginning of the report, in the first four or five lines. The message is "JOB FAILED". If this message is present, please give the entire output to a system programer. He will help you in locating and correcting the error. If the message is not present, then the run ta terminated normally.
 - 19 - There are two most common reasons for a system failure. The first reason is due to IBM control cards errors (JCL errors). This is indicated by the message: JOB FAILED - JCL ERROR The second reason is due to the fact that there may not be enough space in the computer to run the model. This is indicated by the message: JOB FAILED - WAITING FOR ALLOCATION Other errors may occur occasionally. However, if they do, they all require assistance from a system programmer as mentioned above. Master File Listing A listing of the data content of the master file is produced only in B or U-runs. If the master file does not contain all input data, check the Error Messages Report to determine the cause.  - 20 - Input Listing All valid data input is formated for easy reading and printed on this report. The user should check the listing to insure that the model has received all the input required for the particular run. Educational Simulation Model Report This report is always produced in each projection run. It includes, for each projection year, enrollment, promotion, repetition, and dropout rates, and number of dropouts for each course in the ESM structure. Compound Model Reports The names of the Compound Model reports and their Report IDs are listed in the following table. Samples of all reports are found in Section 10. Compound Model reports are produced on demand for the projection years specified on card "C03" and for the report IDs specified on card "G05" (see Section 6). Highlights Report This manpower projections summary report is always produced in each run. For a sample, see Section 10

 - 24 - SECTION 5 INPUT - GENERAL DESCRIPTION Introduction The input to the system can be classified into the following seven major types: Type C: Run control cards, informing the system about the type of run being requested. Type D: Manpower demand or requirements cards, informing the system about labor demand and methods of estimating requirements. Type E: Education simulation cards, specifying educational structure, enrollment, intakes, promotion/reQetition/ dropout rates, etc. Type G: General data cards, defining sector/occupation/ nationality IDs, reports selection, etc. Type L: Labor force data cards, containing information about existing labor force, attrition rates, etc. Type P: Manpower policy data cards, informing the system about manpower allocation priorities, extent of nationalization, and expatriate manpower con- straints.
 -25- Type S: Manpower supply cards, informing the system about labor force participation patterns, school leavers pooling, teacher stock, etc. Input cards have been designed to allow the user to enter the required data into the system, and to select processing options and methods. The specifications and layouts of the cards are described in details in Section 6. However, before turning to that section, the user should become familiar with the general input card format which is described in the following paragraphs. General Input Card Format Although data items vary for each card type, the first ten columns of each type contain card identification information which is used consistently throughout all input cards. The items of information and their location in the cards are described below: Card Column 1: contains an alphabetic character identifying the card type. The valid characters are those listed in the introduction to this section. Card Columns : contain a two-digit number which further identifies the 2 and 3 kind of data pertaining to the card type in column 1. Valid numbers are indicated in Section 6 for each input.
 - 26 - Card Columns: contain a three-digit card sequence number to 4, 5, and 6 identify further each card in a card type set. The valid range of sequence numbers is from 001 to 998. Card Columns: this field is made available to the user for his 7, 8, 9, and 10 own card identification purposes. Although not used by the system, the supplementary identification is retained and printed with the content of the card whenever an input listing is generated. The remaining portion of the card (columns 11 to 80) varies in meaning and content depending on the particular card type.
 - 27 - Field Types Data fields coded on the input cards are of four different types: A: Alphabetic N: Numeric ND: Numeric decimal A/N: Alpha numeric Alphabetic type data fields may contain the entire repiwtoire of characters available in the computer, except the digits 0 to 9. Numeric type data fields may contain the diRits 0 to 9, the operational signs "+ -", and blanks (see explanatory Note 1 below). Numeric decimal type data fields have the same definition as numeric types, but they may also contain a decimal point (see expla- natory Note 2 below). Alphanumeric type data fields may contain the entire repertoire of characters available in the computer.
 - 28 - Note 1 (Numeric type) Assuming that the input card data field is 6 characters long, and that the value to be entered is equal to 123, then the field must be coded in the following way: I l I12 3 1 However, preceding blanks may also be coded as zeros: i.e. f 0 1 2 3 0 1 2 3 o 1 2 3 0 0 1 2 3 0 0 1 2 3 0 0 1 2 3 0 0 0 1 12 131 Unsigned values are taken as positive. (None of the data fields of the Compound Model, as currently implemented, allow for the entry of negative values.)
 - 29 - Note 2 (Numeric decimal'type) Assuming that the input card data field is 6 character long, and that the value to be entered is equal to 12.3, then the field may be coded in either of the following ways: i 1 2 3 LI 12 3 That is, the position of the decimal point is immaterial as long as it is contained within the data field. Furthermore, preceding and/or trailing blanks may be coded as zeros without altering the value of the data. i.e. 1 2 * 3 T may also be coded as 0 1 2 3 0o or 1 2 3* 3 0 or Unsigned values are taken as positive. (None of the data fields of the Compound Model, as currently implemented, allow for the entry of negative values.)

 - 33 - SECTION 6 INPUT - DETAILED DESCRIPTION Introduction This section describes in details the contents and layout of each input card type. The specifications are organized in alpha- numeric sequence, starting with card "COl" and ending with card "SlO". Each of the seven major types (i.e. C, D, E, G, L, P, and S) is preceded by a general description of the card type and by specifications regarding its use. A list of all card types is presented in Section 5.
 - 34 - Section 6.1 CARD TYPE C - RUN CONTROL CARDS The run control cards allow the user to: - select the type of run being requested (base year, stimulation, or updating run); - specify the name(s) of the master file(s) to be used in the run; - enter reports title; - specify base year and last projection years; and - specify the projection years for which.reports are to be generated. The run control cards comprise the following card types: CO1, C02, and C03. The entire set of cards is always required in any projection runs.
 - 35 - CARD TYPE: CO1 CARD NAME: Run Control PURPOSE : The COI card identifies which type of run will be executed and the Master File required during the execution. The. types of runs are: s B for Base Year runs - S for Simulation runs - U for Master File Update runs For more information, see gection 3. The Master File ID is a user provided file name which uniquely identifies a master. file. NUMBER OF CARDS : One card REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required NOTES, The CO1 card must be the first card in the input deck.
 CARD TYPE: COl CARD NAME: Run Control CARD FIELD FIELD NAME FIELD DESCRIPTION COLUMN LENGTH TYPE 1 - 3 3 Card Type A/N Enter "COl" 4 - 6 3 Sequence Number N Enter "001" 7 -10 4 Open A/N Available to user for card identification purposes 11 1 Run Type Indicator A Enter "B" for Base Year run "S" for Simulation run "U" for Update run 12-23 22 New Master File ID A/N Enter new Master File ID for "B" and "U" runs Leave blank for "S" runs 24-35 22 Old Master File ID A/N Enter old Master File ID for "S" and "U" runs .Leave blank for "B" runs 1/ A = Alphabetic N = Numeric A/N - Alphanumeric

The description contained in the card is printed as title of the reports generated by the system. NUMBER OF CARDS : One or more cards (see Notes) REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required NOTES If more than one card are used for the title, only the content of the first card is printed as title for the reports. The contents of the remaining cards are displayed only on the title page preceding the reports.

 - 41 - CARD TYPE: C03 CARD NAME: Years of Projection PURPOSE: The C03 card is used to define the base year and the last year of projection. It is also used to indicate the years for which reports are to be produced. The maximum number of years of projection is 15. NUMBER OF CARDS: One card REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required NOTES: The last year of projection must be greater than the base year. The years for which reports are desired (max. of 15) must be greater than the base year and less than or equal to the last year of projection. They must be entered sequentially in ascending order.

 - 44 - SECTION 6.2. CARD TYPE D - MANPOWER DEMAND/REOUIREMENTS CARDS The manpower demands/requirements card set contains 14 card types ranging from DO1 to D20 as follows: DO1, D02, D03, D05, D06, D08 to D14, D19, and D20. Card DO1 allows the user to indicate his choice among three methods of estimating manpower requirements for each individual sector. These methods are: i) The Elasticity Method - identified as Method 1. ii) The Productivity Method - identified as Method 2. iii) The Direct Input Method - identified as Method 3. Only one method can be used for any individual sector, but various sectors within a country can use different methods. For example, it is possible to use the elasticity method (Method 1) for the Construction Sector, the productivity method CMethod 2) for other Manufacturing Sector, and the direct input method (Method 3) for the Petroleum Sector. Regardless of the method indicated in DO1 (1,2, or 31, the following D cards must be prepared: Must Cards DO1 - Method of Manpower Requirement Estimation D02 - Base Year Sectoral Output D20 - Sector/Occupation Distribution Matrix
 - 45 - If Method 1, the elasticity method, is selected, three cards in addition to the three must cards should be prepared: D10 - expected annual GNP growth rates D13 - sectoral elasticittes D14 - base year sectoral employment When Method 2, the productivity method, is selected, three cards in addition to the three must cards should be prepared. These are: i) D08 - base year sectoral productivity ii) choose one among three possible approaches to enter sectoral output for the years beyond the base year as follows: ( D03 - if sectoral output is to be entered for each year ( c of projection Cstreaming) Select ( C D05 - if sectoral output growth rates are used One ( ( D06 - if interpolation is to be used to calculate ( sectoral output between base year and final ( year of projection iii) Choose one among three possible approaches to enter sectoral productivity for the years beyond the base year. ( D09 - if productivity is to be entered for each year C 8 of projection (streaming) Select ( Dll - if productivity growth rates are used One ( D12 - if interpolation is to be used to calculate ( sectoral productivity between the base ( year and final year of projection
 - 46 - When using Method 3, direct input, two cards in addition to the three must cards, should be prepared. They are: D03 - sectoral output for each year of projection (streaming) D19 - sector employment for each year of projection (streaming).

 - 69 - CARD TYPE: D10 CARD NAME: Annutal MNP Growth Rates PURPOSE The D10 card allows the user to specify the GNP annual growth rate for each projection year. It is used for: Method 1, elasticity method. In addition, it also contains sector IDs for those sectors which are included in the calculation of GNP total but are not using Method 1 to estimate manpower requirements. The sector IDs must be defined in card "G02". NUMBER OF CARDS : One or more cards REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required for the condition stated above. NOTES' The sector IDs must be coded exactly as they appear on card The rates entered in the card apply to that year and to subsequent years until replaced by another D10 card containing the new year in columns 11-14. Rates entered in the card must be positive.

 - 90 - SECTION 6.3. CARD TYPE E - EDUCATION SIMULATION DATA CARDS The education simulation cards allow the user to specify - educational structure in terms of courses and educational levels; - base year enrollment (see note below); - intake levels and growth rates; - promotion, repetition, dropout rates; - promotes disposition to follow-on courses; - student/teacher ratios; and - population data by age to derive intakes. The set of cards comprises the following card types: EO1 to E04, E06 to E09. The entire set is always required in any projection runs. Note: If, for instance, the Base Year is 1975, the base year enrollment is that for academic year 1975/76.
 - 91 - Relationship Between Adademic Years and Projection Years The Compound Model has been structured to accept input data by way of cards and to display output data in the reports on a nominal calendar year basis, the treatment of academic year data, therefore, requires a note of explanation. The following example will illustrate appropriate handling of this matter. If 1975 is chosen as the base year for the simulation, then'1975 should be entered as the base year on the EOl card. For the E03 card (base year enrollment), the academic year 1975/76 enrollments are entered. The rationale is that the majority of the education system output (dropouts and graduates not proceeding to any follow-on course) in the academic year 1975/76 becomes available to the labor force in 1976. For the E06 card (PRDD and repetition/dropout rates), the year 1976 is equated with the academic year 1975/76. In other words, the rates specified for 1976 will operate on the 1975/76 enrollment specified in the E03 card. For the E07 card (entrance rates/levels), the year 1976 would refer to the academic year 1976/77; 1977 would refer to the academic year 1977/78, etc. The intake for the academic year 1975/76 is implicit in the base year enrollments already entered on E03 cards. For the E08 and E09 cards, the academic year 1975/76 would be referred to as 1976, and 1976/77 as 1977, etc.
 - 92 - CARD TYPE: EO1 CARD NAME: ESM Control PURPOSE : The EO1 card specifies to the system certain control information required to execute the ESM model. The information are: base year; total number of courses in the ESM structure number of age groups; the dummy course numbers, if any, assigned to males and females who never attend school; ranee of cottrse numbers for males; and range of course numbers for females. NUMBER OF CARDS One card REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required NOTES, The base year must be identical to the base year specified on the C03 card. Maximum number of courses allowed is 300 (including dummy courses for males and females who never attended schooly Age groups are defined in the ESM model as: N-1, N, N+l, N+2, N+3, N+4, where N is the ideal age. (i.e., maximum of six age groups).

 - 95 - CARD TYPE: E02 CARD NAME: Educational Level PURPOSE : The E02 card allows the user to enter the educational level of each course in the ESM structure.  - 104 - CARD TYPE: E06 CARD NAME: PRDDs and Repetition/Dropout Rate PURPOSE : The E06 card allows the user to enter repetition/drop- out rates, and PRDDs for each course and for each projection year. NUMBER OF CARDS One or more cards REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required for first projection year. NOTES, Maximum number of courses: 300 The sum of PRDDs for a given course must be less than or equal to 1.0. If less than 1.0, the balance is the proportion of students streamed to the labor force. The sum of repetition and dropout rates must be less than or equal to 1.0. If less then 1.0, the balance is equal to the promotion rate. PRDDs and repetition/dropout rates entered in the card apply to that year and to subsequent years until replaced by another E06 card containing the new year in columns 11-14. E06 cards must be prepared for all courses in the ESM structure.

 - 110 - CARD TYPE: E08 CARD NAME: Population Data PURPOSE : The E08 card allows the user to enter population data or population growth rates for each year of projection. NUMBER OF CARDS : One or more cards REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required for first projection year. NOTES, If population value is greater than 2.0, it is considered a total number. If population value is greater than 0.0 and less than or equal to 2.0, it is considered a fraction of last year population (one year younger). If population equals 0.0, the last year population number or fraction is carried forward to the current year. E08 cards must be prepared for the ages specified in the ESM structure on cards "E04" (taking into account the age groups), starting from age = 1.

 - 116 - SECTION 6.4. CARD TYPE C - GENERAL DATA CARDS The general data cards allow the user to: - define sector/occupation/nationality IDs; - define the report selection to be printed; - specify footnotes to be attached to selected reports; and - indicate the distribution list of generated reports. The set of cards comprises the following card types: GOI to G07. Card types C02 to G05 are always required in any projection runs. The remaining card types are optional.

 - 138 - SECTION 6.5. CARD TYPE L - LABOR FORCE DATA CARDS The labor force data cards allow the user to: - enter existing national labor force by sector/occupation and related attrition rates; and - enter existing expatriate labor force by sector/occupation/ nationality and related attrition rates. The set of cards comprises the following card types: LOI to L04. Card types LO1 to L04 are always required for any projection runs.
 - 139 - CARD TYPE: LO1 CARD NArr: Base Year National Labor Force PUPPOS~T The LO1 card allows the user to provide data on the existing national labor force by sector and occupation. The base year must be defined in card "C03", columns 11-14. The sector/occupation IDs entered on this card must be defined in card "G02" and card "G03". NUMBER OF CARDS One or more cards REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Reqiiired NOTES, Sector/occupation IDs must be coded exactly as they appear on cards "G02" and "G03".

 - 142 - CARD TYPE: L02 CARDT) Fk'T National Labor Force Attrition PUPPOSE The L02 card allows the user to specify attrition rates for national labor force by projection year, and by sector/occupation. The sector/occupation IDs entered on this card must be defined in cards "G02" and "G03". Sector/occupation IDs must be coded exactly as they appear on cards "G02" and "G03". NUMBER OF CARDS : One or more cards REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required for first projection year. NOTES, If attrition rates are not entered for specific sectors/ occupations, those rates are assumed to be zero. If attrition rates are different from year to year, they must be entered each year. Rates entered for a particular year will be used for sub- sequent years if L02 cards for subsequent years are not present. If "ALL" is entered for a sector ID, all sectors of a given occupation will use the same attrition rate. If "ALL" is entered for an occupation ID, all occupations of a given sector will use the same attrition rate. If "ALL" is entered for both sector and occupation IDs, all sectors/occupations will use the same attrition rate. Maximum and minimum values for attrition rates are 1.0 and 0.0 respectively.

 - 148 - CARD TYPE: L04 C_RD _NAM: Expatriate Labor Force Attrition The L04 card allows the user to specify attrition rates for expatriate labor force by projection year, and by sector/ occupation/nationality. The sector/occupation/nationality IDs entered on this card must be defined in cards "G02", "G03", and "G04". Sector/occupation/nationality IDs must be coded exactly as they appear on cards "G02", "G03", and "G04". NUMBER OF CARDS * One or more cards REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Requi-red for first projection year. NOTES If attrition rates are not entered for specific sector/ occupation/nationality, those rates are assumed to be zero. If attrition rates are different from year to year, they must be entered each year. Rates entered for a particular year will be used for sub- sequent years if LO4 cards for subsequent years are not present. If "ALL" is entered for a sector ID, all sectors of a given occupation/nationality will use the same attrition rate. If "ALL" is entered for an occupation ID, all occupations of a given'sector/nationality will use the same attrition rate. If "ALL" is entered for a nationality ID, all nationalities of a given sector/occupation will use the same attrition rates. If "ALL" is entered for sector/occupation/nationality IDs all sectors, .occupations, and nationalities will use the same rate. Maximum and minimum values for attrition rates are 1.0 and 0.0 respectively.

 - 151 - SECTION 6.6. CARD TYPE P - MANPOWER POLICY DATA CARDS The manpower policy data cards allow the user to: - define manpower allocations and priorities; - define the extent of nationalization for each sector/ occupation; and - define expatriate manpower constraints in terms of nationalities, range of expatriate employment, and expatriate employment growth rates. The set comprises the following card types. P01, P03, P07, and P08. The entire set is always required in any projection runs.
 - 152 - CARD TYPE: P01 CARD NAME: Priority Matrix and Nationalization Targets PURPOSE : The P01 card allows the user to specify the priority of each sector/occupation in the allocation of school leavers from pools, and the fraction (%) of nationalization target of given sector/occupation classifications. It also specifie the relation of each pool number to the sector/occupation classification. Sector/occupation IDs must be defined in cards "G02" and "G03". Pool numbers must be specified in card "S06". The information may be entered for each projection year. NUMBER OF CARDS : One or vore cards. REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required for first projection year. NOTES' Sector/occupation IDs must be coded exactly as they appear on cards "G02" and "G03". Pool numbers must be entered for every sector/occupation. More than one sector/occupation can be related to a pool number. Only one pool number can be related to a specific sector/ occupation. Priority is optional, but, if entered, 9 indicates the highest priority and zero (or blank) the lowest. The information entered on this card applies to that year and to subsequent years until replaced by another P01 card con- taining the new year in columns 11-14.

 - 163 - SECTION 6.7. CARD TYPE S - MANPOWER SUPPLY CARDS The manpower supply cards allow the user to: - define labor force participation patterns; school leavers pooling; teacher stock, and attrition rates; - define minimum legal age to work; underage school leavers; and underage labor force participation; - define teacher entrance qualifications by teacher groups; and - enter any other additional national labor forces that are not accounted for by the education structure. The set of cards comprises the following card types: SO1 to S10. Card types SO1 to S08 are always required in any projection runs. Card types S09 and S10 are optional. Card S04: Steps involved in computing the number of dropouts of yesteryears who were below the legal age of entry into the labor market prior to the base year. 1. Establish the base year. 2. Establish the ideal age of entry into the first grade. 3. Establish the legal age of entry into the labor market. 4. Compute the number of years immediately preceding the base year for which dropout data will be needed.
 - 164 - ) Legal Age of Entry into the labor Number of years one needs ) ) market minus ideal age of entry to go back for dropout data) ) into the first grade Example: Base year is 1975, Legal Age of Entry into the labor market is 15 and the Ideal Age of Entry into the first grade is 6. Then, the number of years one needs to go back is 15 - 6 i 9 i.e., 1974-75, 1973-74, 1972-73, 1971-72, 1970-71, 1969-70, 1968-69, 1967-68, and 1966-67. 5. The number of grades yielding the dropouts to be included in this exercise is the same as the number of years one needs to go back from the base year, i.e., 9 in the above example. In other words, for the set of assumptions made in the example above, one would need information on stu- dents dropping out from grades 1 to 9 during years 1966-67 to 1974-75, separately for males and females, but not from all grades in each of the above years, as explained below. 6. Obtain the number of students who dropped out of the lowest grade in the earliest year of the time span defined in 4. above, i.e., from grade 1 in 1966-67 in this example. Unless information is available on the age distribution of these dropouts, estimate the number of 5 year olds.
 - 165 - who dropped out of grade 1 in 1966-67 , i.e., ideal age of entry minus one group. If the age distribution of neither the enrollees in grade 1 in 1966-67 nor the dropouts from it is available, one can use the corres- ponding age distribution available for the year closest to 1966-67 assuming that the age distribution of enroll- ment in a grade does not usually change significantly from one year to another, and that the pupils dropout from all age groups represented in a grade in more or less the same proportion. 7. Obtain the number of students who dropped out of grade 1 and grade 2, respectively, during the next following year, i.e., 1967-68. For grade 1 dropouts, obtain or estimate the numbers who were 5 years old and those who were 6 2/ years old , i.e., ideal age of entry minus one group and ideal age of entry group. For grade 2 dropouts, obtain or estimate the numbers representing ideal age of entry 2/ minus one group (6 years old7 Anyone dropping out of grade 1 in 1966-67 who was then 6 years old or older will have reached minimum legal age of entry into the labor market in the base year, and is, therefore, not included in these calculations. Anyone seven years old or older in 1967-68 is of age 15 CLegal age of entry into the labor market) in the base year 1975, and is, therefore, not included in these calculations.
 - 166 - 8. Obtain the number of students who dropped out of grades 1, 2, and 3, respectively, during the next following year, i.e., 1968-69. Among the first grade dropouts, obtain or estimate the numbers representing ideal age minus one, ideal age and ideal age plus one groups, i.e. 5, 6, and 7 year olds. Among the second grade dropouts, obtain 6r estimate the numbers representing ideal age minus one and ideal age groups, i.e., 6 and 7 year olds, Among the grade three dropouts, obtain or estimate the numbers representing the ideal age minus one group,i.e., 7 year olds 9. The pattern is now clear. For each succeeding year one more grade is included and the cut-off age is increased by one year. In 1974-75, dropouts from grades 1 to 9 are considered ranging from ideal age minus one group for grade 9, i.e., 14 year olds; ideal minus one ar.d ideal age group for grade 8, i.e., 13 and 14 year olds; ideal minus one, ideal and ideal plus one age group for grade 7, i.e., 12, 13 and 14 year olds; and so on, inclu- ding one more age group for each lower grade dropout until all six age groups have been included. 10. Group the dropouts by the grades they dropped out from, showing their age at dropout time along the columni and the year of their dropping out along the rows, as shown in Table 1 for grade 1 dropouts. Each cell of the matrix
 - 167 - containing x represents a number computed in steps 6 to 9 above. Sulmming along the diagonals provides totals Cthe right most column of the table) by age in the base year, of those who dropped out of grade 1. Similar tables can be constructed for dropouts from grades 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 , 7 , 8, and 9. For each higher grade, the matrix will have one less column (losing the left most column) and one less row Closing the top most row); for example, for grade 2 dropouts, age will range from 6 to 14 and years from 1966/67 to 1974/75. Table 1: Grade 1 Dropouts (Ideal Age 6 years) AGE 66/67 67/68 68/69 69/70 70/71 71/72 72/73 73/74 74/75 TOTAL 7 x x 9 10 11 12 13 14
 - 168 - 11. The ten tables produced above Cone each for dropouts from grade 1 to 10) can now be consolidated into one table as shown below where each x in a cell represents a diagonal total obtained in step 10 above. One addi- tional column is added for "never entered school". Note that if ideal age of entry is six for first grade, the age series will begin at six, Table 2 Age Never in the entered D opouts From Base Year School Gr.lIGr.2. Data is entered by course number and by projection year. NLIIBER OF CARDS : One or more cards REQUIRED/OPTIONAL: Required for first projection year NOTES The maximum number of pools allowed by the system is 288. The information entered on this card applies to that year and to subsequent years until replaced by a new S06 card containing the new year in columns 11-14.

 - 199 - SECTION 7 SAMPLE'COMPUTER'RUN'SET'UP This section describes the typical input data required in a projection run. The input data can be classified into two categories: IBM computer system control cards and Compound Model'input cards. The IBM Control Cards are referred to as JCL or Job Con- trol Language cards. This set of cards are installation dependent and vary from installation to installation. A list of JCL cards required to run the model as installed on the George Washington University IBM system oNashington D. C.) is presented in this section. However, the user does not have to enter the entire set of JCL cards each time he runs a projection, since the JCL set can be saved permanently on IBM system files. All he should need to enter are the three following cards: 1/ //JOBNAME JOB (800346,N,30,50,30),'USERNAME' 1/ EXEC MANPOWER, COPIES*n (where n-number of reports copies desired) // These cards must be the first, second, and the last card of the input deck. 1/ The JOBNAME card is installation dependent
 - 200 - The Compouwid-Model - i cttards have been described in prior sections. The entire set must be inserted in the input deck after the "EXEC MANPOWER" JCL card and before the "//" JCL card. Notice thatv`the "COl" card must be the-first card of the Compound Model input set. In summary, the organization of the input deck to the Compound Model is: JCL "JOB" Card 1st card JCL "EXEC" Card 2nd card CO1 Card 3rd card C02 to S10 Cards Following 3rd card JCL "//" Card Last card

 - 203 - SECTION 8 DIAGNOSTIC'MESSAGES A complete list of user messages generated by the system is presented in this section. In addition to error messages, the list also includes the cause of the error and the action that the user should take to correct it. It should be noted that there are other error messages generated by the IBM computer system that are not listed in this section. If these messages- occur, the-user should consult the appropriate IBM manuals or request assistance from a systems analyst. If the level of error severity is indicated as'iCnor (error code of 4 from Edit step), processing is continued. If the level of error severity is indicated aa iMjor Cerror code of 8 from Edit step)-, processing is stopped after completing the editing of all input.

 - 213 - SECTION 9 SAPLE INPUT The data cards listed in this section are for a sample run of an economic model eonsisting of three private and one public sectors, each containing three occupational categories. Manpower supplies for the economy come from existing labor force, from manpower supplied by the educational system, and from manpower supplied by importation of labor from two expatriate groups. The school system described in the sample is composed of 111 courses and six teacher groups. The school leavers that are avai- lable for the labor force, are collected into five pools, from which needed manpower is drawn. Distribution of school leavers is determined by national priorities and the desired fraction of nationalization by sector and occupation is inpit to determine the allocation of pooled school leavers to the labor force. The output from the sample run is presented in Section 10,

doc.repnme: Tools for manpower planning : the World Bank models / user's guide for the country (compound) model - volume II
doc.abstracts: The Country (Compound) Model is one of a set of simulation models developed during a research project to study the implications of the explosion of international migration in the Middle East and North Africa Region for both labor-importing and labor-exporting countries. The models have been applied to study manpower problems and planning issues in several countries and was proven to be a useful tool. This user's guide describes the input, output, use, and operation of the model, which is a manpower forecasting model, implemented for IBM 370 systems.
